concepts.title: Shakespeare ‚Äî 'Under the Greenwood Tree' and 'Home Sweet Home'
concepts.content: Shakespeare's song from 'As You Like It' invites anyone who has given up ambition to come live freely in the forest. 'Home Sweet Home' by John Howard Payne is a beloved song about longing for one's home: 'Be it ever so humble, there's no place like home.' Both poems celebrate simple, natural joys over wealth and power.

examples.text: 'Come hither, come hither!' ‚Äî Shakespeare's invitation to the simple life
'Be it ever so humble, there's no place like home'
'No enemy but winter and rough weather' ‚Äî nature is not cruel, only weather
'I gaze on the moon...And feel that my mother now thinks of her child'

keyPoints: Shakespeare (16th century): greatest English playwright
'Under the Greenwood Tree' from the play 'As You Like It'
'Hither' = towards here; 'doth' = does (Old English)
'Ambition': desire for wealth, power, fame
Home Sweet Home: exile longs for simple cottage, mother's love
concepts.funFact: üé≠ Shakespeare wrote 37 plays and 154 sonnets ‚Äî and he used over 17,000 different words, inventing many himself!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 79-80: Under the Greenwood Tree; Pages 95-96: Home Sweet Home

concepts.title: Story ‚Äî 'Unke Munke Timpetoo' (Friendship and Kindness)
concepts.content: Rohan desperately wants a table tennis set for his birthday. His friend Muk tells him about a magic chant: 'Unke, Munke, Timpetoo'. They sneak into old Mrs Groover's garden at midnight and get caught. But Mrs Groover ‚Äî feared former principal ‚Äî is actually kind and lets Rohan finish his rounds. On his birthday, a mysterious parcel arrives from 'Unke, Munke, Timpetoo' containing the table tennis set!

examples.text: Midnight adventure: sneaking into garden, the dog barks, Mrs Groover comes out
Surprise birthday gift from 'Unke, Munke, Timpetoo'
Mrs Groover invites Rohan for tea ‚Äî 'she looked almost human!'
Moral: Unke Munke Timpetoo = the magic of genuine human friendliness

keyPoints: Superstition vs. reality: the 'magic' is really human kindness
First impressions can be wrong (Mrs Groover seemed scary but was kind)
Courage: Rohan confesses everything honestly to Mrs Groover
Friendship: acts of kindness create real connections
Prefix: non+stop=non-stop; un+tie=untie; dis+like=dislike
concepts.funFact: üéÅ The mystery of who sent the table tennis set ‚Äî was it Mrs Groover? ‚Äî is never revealed. That's the magic of the story!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 81-85: Unke Munke Timpetoo by Sigrun Srivastava

concepts.title: Mystery ‚Äî 'The Red-Headed League' (Sherlock Holmes)
concepts.content: Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes story: Mr Wilson's assistant Spaulding convinces him to join the 'Red-Headed League' ‚Äî copying encyclopaedia for ¬£4/week. When the League suddenly 'dissolves', Holmes investigates. The trick: the League kept Mr Wilson away from his shop while Spaulding (alias criminal Clay) dug a tunnel from Wilson's cellar to a nearby bank's gold vault!

examples.text: Holmes' clues: assistant works for half wages; dirty knees from digging
The Red-Headed League: clever scheme to keep Mr Wilson at office daily
Tunnel: from Wilson's cellar to the City Bank's gold vault
Clay caught red-handed in the cellar by Holmes, Watson and police

keyPoints: Detective story elements: mystery, investigation, clues, deduction, resolution
Sherlock Holmes: greatest fictional detective, created by Arthur Conan Doyle
Induction/deduction: Holmes reasons from small clues to big conclusions
Modal verbs: 'I don't know what I'm up against'; 'A crime is being planned'
Synonym: good=nice; Antonym: strong‚â†weak; Homonym: round (adj/noun)
concepts.funFact: üîç Sherlock Holmes is the most portrayed fictional character ever ‚Äî he has appeared in over 25,000 stage adaptations, films and TV shows!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 86-93: The Red-Headed League by Arthur Conan Doyle

concepts.title: Grammar ‚Äî Modal Auxiliary Verbs and Word Formation
concepts.content: Modal auxiliary verbs (can, could, may, might, shall, will, would, should, must, ought to) modify the main verb to show ability, possibility, permission, or obligation. Prefixes add meaning at the front of a word (un-, dis-, non-, super-, inter-). Suffixes add meaning at the end (-er, -ness, -ly, -ful, -able, -ship, -hood).

examples.text: Can: ability ‚Äî 'They can swim'; May: permission ‚Äî 'May I come in?'
Must: obligation ‚Äî 'You must go'; Could: past ability/polite request
Prefix: un+tie=untie; dis+like=dislike; non+stop=non-stop
Suffix: teach+er=teacher; kind+ness=kindness; friend+ship=friendship

keyPoints: Modal auxiliaries: can, could, may, might, shall, will, would, should, must
No 'to' before a modal; no '-ed'/'-ing' added to modal
Questions/negatives with modals: 'Can he swim?', 'He cannot swim.'
Prefix: letters added at front to change meaning
Suffix: letters added at end to make new word
concepts.funFact: üåê 'Can' and 'may' are often confused ‚Äî 'Can I go?' asks about ability; 'May I go?' asks for permission. Both are correct in modern English!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 85, 89: Modal Auxiliaries, Prefix and Suffix

concepts.title: Story ‚Äî 'Papa Panov's Special Christmas' (Leo Tolstoy)
concepts.content: Old Papa Panov, a shoemaker in a Russian village, dreams Jesus will visit him on Christmas Day. He waits all day but only sees ordinary people ‚Äî a cold road sweeper, a young mother with a barefoot baby, beggars. He feeds and helps each of them. At day's end, a voice reveals: 'I was hungry and you fed me... I came to you in everyone you helped.'

examples.text: Papa Panov reads Bible and dreams Jesus will visit on Christmas
Sweeper gets hot coffee; mother gets baby shoes (Papa's best work)
Beggars get hot soup and bread
Jesus: 'I was hungry and you fed me... I came in everyone you helped'

keyPoints: Kindness to strangers = the greatest form of worship
Tolstoy: great Russian writer (also wrote War and Peace, Anna Karenina)
Homophones: no/know, dear/deer, here/hear, pair/pear
Setting: winter Russia, Christmas Eve, village shoemaker
Themes: generosity, empathy, recognising Christ in every person
concepts.funFact: üåç Leo Tolstoy is one of the greatest novelists ever ‚Äî but he also wrote simple folk tales like this to teach moral values to ordinary people!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 99-103: Papa Panov's Special Christmas by Leo Tolstoy

test.question: In 'Under the Greenwood Tree', the poet invites someone who _____.
options: Has given up ambition and loves simple life
test.explanation: 'Who doth ambition shun, And loves to live i' the sun' ‚Äî the poet invites those who have given up desire for wealth and power.

test.question: In 'Unke Munke Timpetoo', what was 'Unke, Munke, Timpetoo' really a symbol of?
options: A brand name of a toy
test.explanation: Mrs Groover says: 'I had wished to have somebody over for tea today. And here you are! Isn't it a perfect example of Unke, Munke, Timpetoo?' ‚Äî the magic is real human connection and kindness.

test.question: How did Sherlock Holmes know the assistant was digging a tunnel?
options: The assistant's trouser knees were wrinkled and stained from digging
He found soil on the assistant's shoes
test.explanation: When Clay answered the door, Holmes noted his trouser knees were wrinkled and stained ‚Äî confirming he was digging.

test.question: Which of these is a modal auxiliary verb?
test.explanation: Modal auxiliary verbs (can, could, may, might, shall, will, should, must, etc.) help the main verb show ability, possibility, permission, or obligation.

test.question: In 'Papa Panov', what did the voice tell Papa Panov at the end of the day?
options: 'I came to you in everyone you helped and welcomed'
'You must go to church to see me'
'The gifts you gave were not enough'
test.explanation: 'I was hungry and you fed me... I came to you today in everyone of those you helped and welcomed.' ‚Äî Jesus appeared in the forms of all those Papa Panov helped.

test.question: The moral of 'Home Sweet Home' is _____.
options: No matter how humble, home is the most precious place
Palace life is better than cottage life
test.explanation: 'Be it ever so humble, there's no place like home' ‚Äî the poet values his simple cottage over all the splendour of the world.

test.question: Why did Spaulding (Clay) work for Mr Wilson at half wages?
options: To use Wilson's cellar to dig a tunnel to the bank
He wanted to learn about red hair dye
test.explanation: Clay needed access to Wilson's cellar to dig the tunnel to the bank's gold vault. Working for half wages was his way of gaining that access.

test.question: What gift did Papa Panov give to the young mother's baby?
options: A pair of tiny leather shoes ‚Äî the best he ever made
test.explanation: Papa Panov had kept a perfect pair of tiny leather shoes ‚Äî the best he'd ever made ‚Äî for Jesus. He decided to give them to the cold-footed baby instead.

test.question: Which is an example of a prefix?
test.explanation: A prefix is added at the FRONT of a word: 'dis' + 'like' = 'dislike'. The others are suffixes (added at the end).

test.question: Synonyms are words that _____.
options: Have the same or nearly the same meaning
Sound the same but mean differently
test.explanation: Synonyms are words from the same language with the same or nearly the same meaning. Example: good‚Äìnice‚Äìpretty.

keyConcepts: Shakespeare's 'Under the Greenwood Tree': simple life over ambition
Unke Munke Timpetoo: kindness and friendship are real magic
Sherlock Holmes: deduction from small clues to solve big mysteries
Modal auxiliaries: can, could, may, might, shall, will, would, should, must
Prefix: letters added to front of word to change meaning
Suffix: letters added to end to form new word
Papa Panov: every person you help = a form of the divine
commonMisconceptions: Modals use -ed/-ing endings ‚Äî FALSE, modals never change form
The Red-Headed League is about hair ‚Äî FALSE, hair is just the trick to keep Wilson away
Papa Panov didn't see Jesus ‚Äî he DID, in every person he helped
Prefix and suffix are the same ‚Äî FALSE, prefix goes before, suffix goes after
realWorldExamples: Shakespeare's plays performed in schools ‚Äî connect to 'As You Like It'
Detective shows on TV use Sherlock Holmes' method of deduction
Papa Panov's message: serve others during festivals, not just celebrate
Superstitions like Unke Munke: charms vs actual human effort and kindness
Home Sweet Home: soldiers, migrants and students living away from home

longAnswers.question: In 'Unke Munke Timpetoo', what was 'Unke, Munke, Timpetoo' really a symbol of?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: On the surface, 'Unke Munke Timpetoo' is just a set of made-up nonsense words with no literal translation. However, in the story, it symbolises the true magic of human kindness and genuine friendship. Rohan's belief in it gave him courage, and Mrs Groover's kindness in sending the table tennis set was the real magic. Ultimately, it represents believing in hope and the joy of making a child's wish come true.
keyPoints: It is a set of made-up nonsense words.
Symbolises the true magic of human kindness and friendship.
Represents Rohan's courage and Mrs Groover's generous act.
Stands for believing in hope and making wishes come true.

longAnswers.question: How did Sherlock Holmes know the assistant was digging a tunnel?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Sherlock Holmes deduced that the assistant, Vincent Spaulding, was digging a tunnel by carefully observing his trousers. When Holmes visited Jabez Wilson's shop, he noticed that the knees of Spaulding's trousers were worn, wrinkled, and stained with dirt. He also tapped the pavement outside the shop to check if it was hollow underneath. These clues confirmed his suspicion that the assistant spent hours in the cellar digging a tunnel to the nearby bank.
keyPoints: Holmes observed the worn and dirt-stained knees of the assistant's trousers.
He tapped the pavement outside the shop to check for a hollow space.
The assistant spent a lot of time in the cellar supposedly developing photos.
These combined clues confirmed the assistant was digging a tunnel.

longAnswers.question: In 'Papa Panov', what did the voice tell Papa Panov at the end of the day?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: At the end of the day, a gentle voice spoke to Papa Panov in his quiet room, revealing the true meaning of his Christmas. The voice told him that Jesus had indeed visited him that day, not as a single grand figure, but in the form of the people he had helped. Jesus was the sweeper he warmed, the young mother and baby he sheltered, and the beggars he fed. The voice affirmed that whatever Papa Panov did for those in need, he did it for Jesus.
keyPoints: The voice revealed that Jesus had visited him throughout the day.
Jesus came in the form of the sweeper, the mother, the baby, and the beggars.
Helping those in need was equivalent to helping Jesus himself.
It showed the true spirit of Christmas lies in kindness and charity.

longAnswers.question: Why did Spaulding (John Clay) work for Mr Wilson at half wages?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Vincent Spaulding, who was actually the notorious criminal John Clay, worked for Mr. Wilson at half wages so he could secure the job easily. His real motive was not to earn a living as a pawnshop assistant, but to gain unrestricted access to the shop's cellar. From the cellar, he needed time and space to secretly dig a tunnel into the vault of the neighboring bank. Accepting lower wages ensured he got the position to carry out his plot.
keyPoints: He wanted to easily secure the job without facing competition.
His real intention was to gain access to the pawnshop's cellar.
He needed to dig a tunnel from the cellar to the nearby bank's vault.
It was a calculated move as part of a larger criminal plot to steal gold.

longAnswers.question: What gift did Papa Panov give to the young mother's baby?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: When the young mother came into Papa Panov's shop to warm herself, he gave her baby a pair of tiny, beautiful leather shoes. Papa Panov had made these shoes himself and considered them his best work. He had originally prepared them as a special gift for Jesus, hoping he would visit on Christmas. However, seeing the baby's bare feet in the harsh cold, his immense compassion led him to give away his most precious creation.
keyPoints: Papa Panov gave the baby a pair of tiny, beautifully crafted leather shoes.
The shoes were his masterpiece and originally meant as a gift for Jesus.
He saw the baby's bare feet in the harsh cold and felt immense pity.
Giving away the shoes demonstrated his deep compassion and selflessness.

longAnswers.question: What did students do during their visit for the 'Seeing Eyes Helping Hands' project?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: As part of the 'Seeing Eyes Helping Hands' project, the students visited a Home for the Aged to spread joy. They actively helped the elderly residents with their daily tasks to make their lives easier. Additionally, the students conducted story-telling sessions and spent quality time listening to the residents' memories. This compassionate effort brought happiness to the elderly and taught the students the true value of empathy and social responsibility.
keyPoints: Students visited a Home for the Aged as part of the project.
They helped the elderly residents with their daily tasks.
They conducted story-telling sessions and listened to the residents' memories.
The visit brought joy to the elderly and taught the students empathy.
